page.title: 09The Pier In Skegness
page.content: The pier opened in 1881 as a tourist attraction. In Queen Victoria's time piers were very popular. The entrance to the pier was replaced in 1937 and again in 1971. In 1919 the ship named 'Europa' of Amsterdam had anchored about a mile or so from the shore. In a storm the skipper was warned by the coxswain of the lifeboat who was Matthew Grunnill, if he didn't drop anchors the tide could carry him through the pier. The Dutchman refused to drop more anchors and at 8 o'clock ran stern first through the pier. In 1978 a storm divided the pier into three parts and the theatre at the end is still isolated in the sea. The pier's arcade is in the land end section. Half way down the pier there is a flight of steps leading up to the middle part of the arcade. Now there are also snack bars on the pier.
